markers.label: Stiff Posture & Clenched Fists
markers.feedback: Throughout the presentation, you're holding a very rigid stance with your fists clenched. This can signal tension or nervousness to the audience. Try relaxing your shoulders and letting your hands rest naturally at your sides. This will make you appear more comfortable and approachable.

markers.label: Monotone delivery
markers.feedback: For the first part of your speech, your vocal pitch is very flat, which can make it difficult for the audience to stay engaged. Try varying your pitch to highlight key emotional points, such as the disappointment of not making it to worlds.

markers.label: Topic misalignment
markers.feedback: The presentation's tone is overwhelmingly negative, which contrasts sharply with the document's core message of resilience, learning from setbacks, and renewed motivation for the future. Ensure your delivery matches the intended story.

markers.label: Speaking pace too slow (<120 WPM)
markers.feedback: The first half of your speech is delivered at a very slow pace. While deliberate speech can be effective, this pace may cause listeners to lose interest. Try starting with a bit more energy.

markers.label: Lacks supporting details
markers.feedback: The presentation states that the team didn't make it to Worlds but omits the crucial context from the document, such as the team's initial successes and the specific unlucky events that led to the outcome. Adding these details would create a much more compelling narrative.

markers.label: Awkward pause (>2 seconds)
markers.feedback: This long 4-second pause breaks the flow of your speech. Try to keep pauses under 2 seconds to maintain audience engagement. A quick breath is all you need.

markers.label: Stuttering
markers.feedback: There's some hesitation and stuttering on the word 'that'. When this happens, it's okay to pause, take a quiet breath, and restart the word or phrase calmly.

markers.label: Low energy
markers.feedback: When you say the experience was 'really unfortunate,' your energy level is quite low. To better convey the emotion behind your words, try matching your vocal energy to the feeling you're describing. This will help your audience connect more with your experience.

markers.label: Fidgeting (Touching Hair)
markers.feedback: There's a moment where you touch your hair, which can be a subconscious self-soothing gesture. To appear more confident, try to keep your hands away from your face and hair. Instead, you can channel that energy into purposeful gestures that emphasize your message.

markers.label: Speaking pace too fast (>180 WPM)
markers.feedback: Your speaking pace accelerates dramatically here, making it difficult to follow. Remember to breathe and give each word space, ensuring your message is clear and not rushed.

markers.label: Rushed pace
markers.feedback: Your speaking pace accelerates significantly here, causing the words to blend together. To improve clarity, try to consciously slow down and use brief pauses between your thoughts. This will give your words more impact and make your story easier to follow.

markers.label: Rushed Pacing with Static Body
markers.feedback: As your speech accelerates, your body remains completely still. This creates a disconnect for the viewer. Allow your body language to match your vocal energy—even small, natural shifts in weight or hand gestures can make your delivery feel more dynamic and engaging.

markers.label: Lack of conclusion
markers.feedback: The presentation ends abruptly without a resolution or key takeaway. Conclude by sharing the powerful lesson learned about resilience and the team's determination for next year, as outlined in your document.

markers.label: Unintelligible Speech
markers.feedback: Your speech trails off into sounds instead of words at the end. It's important to finish your thoughts with clear words. If you feel overwhelmed, pausing to collect your thoughts is a stronger finish.

transcript: I will now talk about my robotics team. We did not make it. We did not make it to worlds. That-that-that-that that is really unfortunate. And at the end of the day, we didn't really have any good experiences and it was really bad and I really didn't have any fun. It was horrible, it was horrible, it was horrible. And then n-n-n-n-n-n-n-n-n-n-n-n-n-n-n-n.
